questions.question: I don’t know …………………… he is innocent.
questions.description: We use whether to introduce indirect yes/no questions.

questions.question: ………………………. she will come I am not sure at the moment.
questions.description: When an indirect question is fronted, we use whether, not if.

questions.question: I asked …………………….. she had met me before.
questions.description: Both whether and if can be used to introduce indirect yes/no questions.

questions.question: This is the closet ………………………. she keeps her things.
questions.description: We need a place word here.

questions.question: The consequence of his stupidity was ……………………….. he soon lost his money.
questions.description:
That is merely a connector. When we split the sentence into two clauses, we get:
He soon lost his money.
It was the consequence of his stupidity.
We can combine them with that.

questions.question: She is beautiful. She is equally intelligent. That means she is as beautiful as ………………..
questions.description: Both clauses have the same pattern in this structure.

questions.question: A cottager and his wife had a hen …………………….. laid a golden egg every day.
questions.description: Both that and which can be used to refer to animals, birds or things.

questions.question: He ran so quickly ……………………… he soon overtook me.
questions.description: The conjunction so…that… is used to indicate ideas such as effect or purpose.

questions.question: He spoke in ……………………… a low voice that nobody could hear him.
Tell me what …………………………. done?
questions.description: In indirect questions, the auxiliary verb goes after the subject.

questions.question: ……………………….. you are drunk aggravates your offence.
questions.description: That-clauses are not normally used alone as subjects. They are often introduced by the expression ‘the fact’.

questions.question: They paid no attention to ………………………. she was depressed.
questions.description: That-clauses after prepositions are introduced by ‘the fact’.
